Equilibrium shapes of liquids and
sessile drops
In this chapter we study the equilibrium shapes of a liquid conÔ¨Åned in a given
container, with particular emphasis on the model problem of the sessile liquid
drop. This is a classical subject, with a huge interdisciplinary literature. There-
fore we shall provide here only a rough introduction to this theory, referring
the reader to the beautiful book [Fin86] for a more complete account. At the
same time, the study of these problems will allow us to provide signiÔ¨Åcant
and instructive applications of the various methods and ideas developed so far.
Since the work of Gauss, the problem is studied through the introduction of a
free energy functional. Precisely, if a liquid occupies a region E inside a given
container A (mathematically, E will be a set of Ô¨Ånite perimeter and A an open
set with suÔ¨Éciently smooth boundary), then its free energy is given by

see Figure 19.1. Here, œÉ>0 denotes the surface tension at the interface be-
tween the liquid and the other medium (be it another liquid or gas) Ô¨Ålling
A. The coeÔ¨Écient Œ≤ is called the relative adhesion coeÔ¨Écient between the
Ô¨Çuid and the bounding solid walls of the recipient, and for reasons to be soon
clariÔ¨Åed (see Theorem 19.8), it satisÔ¨Åes |Œ≤|‚â§1. The term ‚àíœÉŒ≤P(E; ‚àÇA)is
called the wetting energy. Finally, the third term denotes a potential energy
acting on the liquid, which is typically assumed to be the gravitational energy
g(x ) = gœÅ x
n

and g is the acceleration of gravity. In the following, in order to simplify the
notation, we shall always set œÉ = 1.
The free energy functional is usually minimized under a prescribed vol-
ume constraint |E| = m. The corresponding variational problems will be the
object of our discussion. We will start in Section 19.1, applying the Direct
Method to prove an existence result in bounded containers, and deriving the

corresponding stationarity conditions, including the boundary stationarity con-
dition known as Young‚Äôs law. We shall then focus on the case that A is a half-
space, thus setting the stage for the study of sessile liquid drops. In Section 19.2
we present the Schwartz inequality, a powerful geometric tool that we will ap-
ply in Section 19.3 to solve a constrained relative isoperimetric problem in
the half-space, and in Section 19.5 to prove a useful symmetrization principle.
In Section 19.4 we combine these results to characterize equilibrium conÔ¨Ågu-
rations (in half-spaces) in the absence of gravity. This result will provide the
starting point for the analysis of equilibrium conÔ¨Ågurations in the presence
of gravity, the so-called sessile drops, in Section 19.6. In particular, we shall
prove the existence, boundedness, and rotational symmetry of sessile drops.
These results, combined with the regularity theory of Part III, will provide
the reader with a full justiÔ¨Åcation of the symmetry and regularity assumptions
usually adopted in the classical literature on this problem.

19.1.2 Stationarity conditions
Adopting the methods from Chapter 17, we are now going to prove that the
mean curvature of the interior interface of an equilibrium conÔ¨Åguration equals
the potential energy plus a constant additive factor. The wetting energy plays
no role in this result, and indeed no restriction on Œ≤ is required (of course, when
|Œ≤| > 1, non-existence phenomena are expected to occur).

Remark 19.9 Young‚Äôs law is insensitive to the presence of the potential en-
ergy. The contact angle of a liquid drop at equilibrium on a horizontal plane is
determined by the capillarity eÔ¨Äects only, which turn out to be much stronger
than gravity eÔ¨Äects. Gravity, of course, inÔ¨Çuences the equilibrium shape away
from the contact plane, for example, by Ô¨Çattening the liquid drop at its top.
Remark 19.10 By Remark 19.6, Young‚Äôs law implies that a relative isoperi-
metric set E in A, with A ‚à© ‚àÇE regular enough, intersects the boundary of A
orthogonally; see Figure 12.8. Similarly, a Cheeger set E in A, with A‚à©‚àÇE reg-
ular enough, has to intersect the boundary of A tangentially; see Figure 19.2.
In the planar case n = 2 one always has enough regularity to apply Young‚Äôs
law to these examples, as follows from the regularity theory of Part III.

19.6 Sessile liquid drops

Theorem 19.24 (Sessile liquid drops) If Œ≤ ‚àà (‚àí1, 1), g>0 and m > 0, then
there exist minimizers in the variational problem (19.67). Every such minimizer
is equivalent to a bounded set, which, up to translation, it is equivalent to its
Schwartz symmetrization.
Remark 19.25 (Regularity, Young‚Äôs law, and uniqueness) In Part III we shall
complete this result by showing that if E is a minimizer in (19.67), then H ‚à©‚àÇE
is an analytic hypersurface. This regularity property makes it possible to fully
exploit the axial symmetry of the liquid drop, as it allows us to write down
the Euler‚ÄìLagrange equation of the problem as a classical ODE satisÔ¨Åed by
the one-dimensional proÔ¨Åle of the drop. The analysis of this ODE shows that
H ‚à© ‚àÇE is analytic up to the boundary (so that Young‚Äôs law is satisÔ¨Åed at
bdry (H ‚à©‚àÇE)), and that, given m and g, the minimizing proÔ¨Åle is unique (thus
providing a global uniqueness result up to horizontal translations).
Remark 19.26 When Œ≤ ‚â• 1 we see that (19.67) admits no minimizer by
looking at the same minimizing sequence constructed in Remark 19.19.
